  • What are the different market instruments?
What are the different market instruments?
What are the different market instruments?


Depending upon your preferences of the expectations of risk and return there is a huge variety of instruments which you can trade from. It is just similar to the flea market which have huge variety of products for different people having different needs. So, people invest in different vehicles of investments depending on their needs for future, their risk preferences, their own choices of returns, time period of return etc. It all depends on the individual and his choice in regard to what he invests in. We have 4 major asset classes:

1. Securities:

a) Fixed Income ( Bonds, Notes, Commercial paper)
b) Equity ( Common Stocks, Preferred Stocks)
c) Pooled Investment Vehicles ( MF, ETF, ABS)

2. Currencies

3. Contracts

4. Commodities

Now let’s start with Fixed Income securities and try to understand what it is. Now, say you are a government of a nation and you want to raise capital for some development purpose, so you can raise money by borrowing it, with a promise of making fixed payments called “coupon” to the lender and in the end paying the face value of the debt. This can be done by a company/ municipality etc to raise money to fund for projects etc. Since, the investment in government bonds is considered to be the safest with lowest possibility of default, such bonds have lower coupon rates than other kind of bonds like corporate bonds. Yet they are less risky than equity securities with fixed monthly/ annual payments.

Investing in equity is what people consider when they hear the term “equity”. This is basically buying and selling stocks of publicly trading companies. This is an easier way of raising capital without the promise of regular payment, companies raise money by offering equity/stake in their companies. This is done by distribution of stocks. Here you can earn money in two ways, one is by dividends, which a lot of companies distribute to their stockholders. This can be taken as earning interest per share or a bonus. The other by buying and selling of the stocks.

You must have heard about Mutual Funds, they belong to another category of market instruments, called the Pooled Investment Vehicles. The term refers to the structures where a lot of investors combine their investments or funds in a particular combination to investment in a particular set of assets. You can invest in mutual funds either from fund itself or in secondary market.

There are other categories in Pooled Investment Vehicles as well it includes Exchange Traded Funds ETFs, Asset-backed Securities and Hedge Funds. Exchange Traded Funds trade like closed-end funds or say Mutual Funds but have special provisions allowing conversion into individual portfolio securities, or exchange of portfolio of shares to ETF shares. They usually track an index, have simple structure and low management fees as low as 0.5 to 1 percent compared to 2 - 3 percent fees in Mutual Funds.

Asset Backed securities this is like a claim or ownership to a proportion of a pool or say bunch of financial assets like mortgages, car loans, or credit card debt. The return from these financial assets is passed on to the investor with different classes of claims depending on risk preference.

Currencies are issued by the central banks of various governments. The special thing about currencies is that they are traded in pair, USDINR, JPYINR, EURINR etc. Therefore they are priced relative to the base currency. The fluctuations in currencies are very high as they are traded by the fluctuations at the fourth place of the decimal.

Contract are agreements between two parties that require some action in the future such as exchanging an asset or cash. Financial contracts are often based on securities, currencies, commodities, or security indexes. They include futures, forwards, options, swaps and insurance contracts.

Commodities are trades on precious metals, agricultural products, industrial metals, energy products. They are traded in spot, futures and forward markets.

What should I expect from stock market?

Most of the people enter the{" "} {" "} stock market{" "} {" "} with very high hopes of doubling quadrupling their money,this expectation is not wrong, it’s just the timeframe in which they wish to achieve such returns is wrong, such returns are possible given you take a time frame of 5 to 15 years. Instead if a more conservative approach of 15-20% return which is much higher than what you get in fixed deposits is more practical and feasible approach towards investing.

You must have heard of the names Warren Buffet, Rakesh Jhunjhunwala, you must have heard different stories of their investment, but the most important thing that is common is the consistency factor, that all of them have been very consistent in their returns ranging around 20- 30% per year. This with the power of compounding is what does the true magic to their fortunes.

So, always remember a target return of 20% is a very decent return one can get by investing in the stock market. As of now sensex trades in a range of Rs. 38,000 up from a range of Rs. 22,000 over a period of 5 years giving 70%. Hence, sensex itself in the long run has outperformed all the investment options like Fixed Deposits, Savings etc. One should invest in different asset classes like gold, fixed income securities to diversify the portfolio which reduces the risk.

{" "} stock market{" "} {" "} is like a roller coaster ride with it’s ups and downs. It gets difficult to take right decisions at right time . But most of the times they are not a rollercoaster ride and you can avoid it by a variety of methods. One by being practical and setting the right kind of goals. Investing in a diverse portfolio reduces your risk to a much larger extent my balancing your overall portfolio. By being rational and not being emotional while investing in stocks and cutting down on losses by selling a stock at a maximum loss of say 10%. Before making a decisions one should do there own research and not rely on rumors and other people. You should keenly and regularly try to monitor your investment. There should be a very disciplined approach to invest. Before investing real money one should do{" "} {" "} backtesting{" "} .

{" "} For more information and for live backtesting click on the link : kuants backtesting Kuants provide user friendly interface for{" "} {" "} algoritmic trading{" "} .
